questions.question: What is TCP?
questions.explanation: TCP: connection-oriented, reliable. Features: sequencing, flow control, error correction. Speed: slower than UDP. Uses: email, file transfer, web. Handshake: 3-way connection. Importance: fundamental protocol.

questions.question: What is UDP?
questions.explanation: UDP: connectionless, unreliable. Speed: faster than TCP. Overhead: minimal. Uses: streaming, gaming, DNS. No handshake: just send. Importance: real-time applications.

questions.question: What is a port?
questions.explanation: Port: 16-bit number. Range: 0-65535. Well-known: 0-1023. Registered: 1024-49151. Dynamic: 49152-65535. Example: 80 (HTTP), 443 (HTTPS). Importance: service identification.

questions.question: What is a socket?
questions.explanation: Socket: IP + port combination. Format: 192.168.1.1:8080. Creation: connect() system call. Purpose: communication endpoint. Bidirectional: two-way communication. Importance: application level.

questions.question: What is HTTP?
questions.explanation: HTTP: stateless, request-response. Ports: 80 (HTTP), 443 (HTTPS). Methods: GET, POST, PUT, DELETE. Status codes: 200, 404, 500. Importance: web foundation. Versions: HTTP/1.1, HTTP/2, HTTP/3.

questions.question: What is HTTPS?
questions.explanation: HTTPS: encrypts data. Protocol: TLS/SSL. Certificates: verify server identity. Cost: minimal performance impact. Port: 443. Importance: security essential. Adoption: now standard.

questions.question: What is FTP?
questions.explanation: FTP: transfer files between computers. Connection: separate control, data. Security: unencrypted (vulnerable). Ports: 21 (control), 20 (data). Alternative: SFTP (secure). Importance: legacy protocol.

questions.question: What is SMTP?
questions.explanation: SMTP: sends emails. Port: 25, 587. Direction: client to server. Outgoing: email transmission. Related: IMAP, POP3 (receiving). Importance: email foundation. Spam: major issue.

questions.question: What is IMAP?
questions.explanation: IMAP: retrieves emails from server. Port: 143, 993 (secure). Advantage: keeps mail on server. vs POP3: POP deletes after download. Synchronization: multiple devices. Importance: modern email.

questions.question: What is DNS query?
questions.answer: Request for domain to IP translation
questions.explanation: Query: recursive or iterative. Recursive: server finds answer. Iterative: referred to other servers. Caching: speeds up lookups. TTL: time-to-live for cache. Importance: web fundamental.
